# Iris Setup

A step by step guide to get Iris up and running.

This guide assumes Windows is the target OS. Furthermore, all the commands are written for PowerShell.

# 1. Install Docker

Project page: https://www.docker.com/ (opens new window)

Head out to https://docs.docker.com/get-docker/ (opens new window) and download and install Docker. Note that if the target OS is windows, a Pro version is required.

You might have to update the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) 2 Linux kernel. Follow the instructions that pop up once the installation of Docker has finished or head to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/wsl2-kernel (opens new window). From there you can download the kernel update package. Install it.

If the WSL has not been enabled yet you will have to enable it. To do so, head to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install-win10#step-1---enable-the-windows-subsystem-for-linux (opens new window) and follow the instructions. After that, try to install the update again.

# 2. Install and Setup Dapr

Project page: https://dapr.io/ (opens new window)

Installation instructions from: https://docs.dapr.io/getting-started/install-dapr-cli/ (opens new window)

To download and install Dapr run the following command on Windows PowerShell:

> iwr -useb https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dapr/cli/master/install/install.ps1 | iex

If an error is raised, you might have to run

> Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -scope CurrentUser

Take into account that until Tye (opens new window) gets updated the version of Dapr that should be used is 0.11. This is due to compatibility reasons. Once the installation of Dapr has finished close the terminal window, open a new one and execute:

> dapr init

If everything went ok, this will launch Dapr. If you run docker ps you should see 3 Dapr containers running. The one called dapr_placement should be stopped (and optionally removed) beacuse it binds to a wrong port. To do so and start the fixed container run:

> docker stop dapr_placement
> docker rm dapr_placement
> docker run --name dapr_placement_fix -p 50005:50005 -d daprio/dapr ./placement

# 3. Install and Setup Tye

Project page: https://github.com/dotnet/tye (opens new window) Installation instructions from: https://github.com/dotnet/tye/blob/master/docs/getting_started.md (opens new window)

On a terminal session run:

> dotnet tool install -g Microsoft.Tye --version "0.5.0-alpha.20555.1"

This should be enough.

# 4. Clone Repositories

Once Docker, Dapr and Tye have been installed and are up and running it is time to clone the desired Iris repositories. For this example we will use RoomBookings (opens new window). Clone it by:

> git clone https://JGIng@dev.azure.com/JGIng/Iris/_git/RoomBookings

# 5. Run

cd into the above cloned repository and run:

> dotnet tool restore
> dotnet build

If this commands fail, check that the XML Documentation files of the projects are pointing to the correct paths. To do so, navigate to

Left CLick on project root > Properties > Build > XML Documentation File

and check the path. It should be .\[PROJECT_NAME].xml. If it is not, change it so that it has this format and save the changes. After that, try running the previous commands again. Additionally, some environment variables have to be set. Please talk to the project manager so he can point out the required changes.

Finally, run:

> .\dev.bat

If everything went ok this command should automatically open the Tye Dashboard at http://127.0.0.1:8000/.
